input:
1. A 12-year-old male presents with progressive difficulty in walking and frequent tripping over the past two years. He has noticeable muscle weakness and atrophy in his lower legs, with a high-stepping gait and foot drop on examination. His parents report he has been hoarse and occasionally chokes while swallowing since early childhood. Neurological assessment reveals diminished deep tendon reflexes and reduced pinprick and vibration sensation in the distal limbs. Electromyography demonstrates predominantly axonal neuropathy. Family history is negative for neuropathy, and genetic testing confirms autosomal recessive mutations associated with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, axonal type, with vocal cord paresis. Laryngoscopy shows bilateral vocal cord paresis contributing to dysphonia. Supportive care with physical therapy and speech therapy is initiated to address functional impairments.
What brings you in today?
output:
THINKING: The patient is quite young and might feel a bit scared or confused about what's happening. They might mention difficulty walking or feeling different in their legs, maybe worried or unsure about what it means. Keep the response simple and based on what they've experienced directly.

ANSWER: Um, I guess I’ve been having a really hard time walking lately. I trip all the time and feel like my legs are really weak, even though I didn’t want them to be. Also, I’ve had like, a hoarse voice and sometimes I choke when I try to swallow, and I don’t really get what’s going on.

input: 1. A 12-year-old male presents with progressive difficulty in walking and frequent tripping over the past two years. He has noticeable muscle weakness and atrophy in his lower legs, with a high-stepping gait and foot drop on examination. His parents report he has been hoarse and occasionally chokes while swallowing since early childhood. Neurological assessment reveals diminished deep tendon reflexes and reduced pinprick and vibration sensation in the distal limbs. Electromyography demonstrates predominantly axonal neuropathy. Family history is negative for neuropathy, and genetic testing confirms autosomal recessive mutations associated with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, axonal type, with vocal cord paresis. Laryngoscopy shows bilateral vocal cord paresis contributing to dysphonia. Supportive care with physical therapy and speech therapy is initiated to address functional impairments.Can you tell me when these symptoms started and how they have changed or progressed over time?
output: Um, I think it’s been like this for maybe two years? It’s kinda gotten a little worse, I guess. Sometimes I trip more than before, and I feel weaker in my feet, but I don’t really remember when it first started exactly.

input: 1. A 12-year-old male presents with progressive difficulty in walking and frequent tripping over the past two years. He has noticeable muscle weakness and atrophy in his lower legs, with a high-stepping gait and foot drop on examination. His parents report he has been hoarse and occasionally chokes while swallowing since early childhood. Neurological assessment reveals diminished deep tendon reflexes and reduced pinprick and vibration sensation in the distal limbs. Electromyography demonstrates predominantly axonal neuropathy. Family history is negative for neuropathy, and genetic testing confirms autosomal recessive mutations associated with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, axonal type, with vocal cord paresis. Laryngoscopy shows bilateral vocal cord paresis contributing to dysphonia. Supportive care with physical therapy and speech therapy is initiated to address functional impairments.Can you tell me more about how your symptoms have affected your daily life, and whether there are particular activities or times of day when they feel worse or better?
output: Um, well, sometimes I trip more in the mornings, I think? And I guess I get tired faster, and I feel kind of off when I try to run or do stuff I used to do easily. It’s just… weird, and I don’t always get why it changes so much.

input: 1. A 12-year-old male presents with progressive difficulty in walking and frequent tripping over the past two years. He has noticeable muscle weakness and atrophy in his lower legs, with a high-stepping gait and foot drop on examination. Neurological assessment reveals diminished deep tendon reflexes and reduced pinprick and vibration sensation in the distal limbs. Electromyography demonstrates predominantly axonal neuropathy. Laryngoscopy shows bilateral vocal cord paresis contributing to dysphonia. Supportive care with physical therapy and speech therapy is initiated to address functional impairments.Can you tell me how these symptoms have influenced your daily activities, and whether there are specific times or situations when your symptoms feel worse or better?
output: Um, I guess I just feel like I get tired and wobbly a lot, especially when I try to walk for a long time or if I’ve been moving around a lot. Sometimes I trip more than usual, and I don’t know, I just feel not quite right in my legs and throat stuff, like it’s harder to talk or swallow sometimes.

input: 1. A 12-year-old male presents with progressive difficulty in walking and frequent tripping over the past two years. He has noticeable muscle weakness and atrophy in his lower legs, with a high-stepping gait and foot drop on examination. His parents report he has been hoarse and occasionally chokes while swallowing since early childhood. Neurological assessment reveals diminished deep tendon reflexes and reduced pinprick and vibration sensation in the distal limbs. Electromyography demonstrates predominantly axonal neuropathy. Family history is negative for neuropathy, and genetic testing confirms autosomal recessive mutations associated with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, axonal type, with vocal cord paresis. Laryngoscopy shows bilateral vocal cord paresis contributing to dysphonia. Supportive care with physical therapy and speech therapy is initiated to address functional impairments.Do you experience any ocular symptoms, such as drooping eyelids (ptosis) or double vision? Also, have you noticed any changes in weight, temperature tolerance, or other systemic symptoms?
output: Um, I don’t think I’ve had anything with my eyes, like droopy eyelids or double vision. And I haven’t really noticed any big changes in my weight or how I feel temperature-wise. Just the walking and choking stuff has been bothering me.

input: 1. A 12-year-old male presents with progressive difficulty in walking and frequent tripping over the past two years. He has noticeable muscle weakness and atrophy in his lower legs, with a high-stepping gait and foot drop on examination. His parents report he has been hoarse and occasionally chokes while swallowing since early childhood. Neurological assessment reveals diminished deep tendon reflexes and reduced pinprick and vibration sensation in the distal limbs. Electromyography demonstrates predominantly axonal neuropathy. Family history is negative for neuropathy, and genetic testing confirms autosomal recessive mutations associated with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, axonal type, with vocal cord paresis. Laryngoscopy shows bilateral vocal cord paresis contributing to dysphonia. Supportive care with physical therapy and speech therapy is initiated to address functional impairments.Are there any signs of autonomic dysfunction, such as dry mouth, constipation, or orthostatic hypotension, that might support LEMS? Additionally, have you noticed any weakness or sensory changes in your arms or hands, or is the weakness primarily in your legs and bulbar muscles?
output: Um, I don’t think I’ve really noticed anything weird in my arms or hands — like, they feel okay, I guess. It’s mostly my legs that keep giving out and I trip a lot, and my voice has been odd too. I haven’t really felt dry or full or anything like that, and I don’t think I feel dizzy or anything when I stand up.

input: 1. A 12-year-old male presents with progressive difficulty in walking and frequent tripping over the past two years. He has noticeable muscle weakness and atrophy in his lower legs, with a high-stepping gait and foot drop on examination. His parents report he has been hoarse and occasionally chokes while swallowing since early childhood. Neurological assessment reveals diminished deep tendon reflexes and reduced pinprick and vibration sensation in the distal limbs. Electromyography demonstrates predominantly axonal neuropathy. Family history is negative for neuropathy, and genetic testing confirms autosomal recessive mutations associated with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, axonal type, with vocal cord paresis. Laryngoscopy shows bilateral vocal cord paresis contributing to dysphonia. Supportive care with physical therapy and speech therapy is initiated to address functional impairments.Have you noticed any episodes or fluctuations in your weakness, such as it improving or worsening at different times of the day, or after rest or activity?
output: Umm, sometimes I feel a little worse when I try to walk a lot, but then it kind of gets tired more easily, and other times it feels okay for a bit. I don’t really know if it gets better after resting, though.

Supportive care with physical therapy and speech therapy is initiated to address functional impairments.Have you noticed how your weakness tends to improve with rest and gets worse with activity, or do you experience fluctuations in your symptoms at different times of the day?
output: Honestly, I think I feel kind of tired or shaky after I walk around a lot, but I don’t really know if it gets better when I sit down or if it switches from one day to another. Sometimes I feel more tired than other times, but I’m not sure why.

input: 1. A 12-year-old male presents with progressive difficulty in walking and frequent tripping over the past two years. He has noticeable muscle weakness and atrophy in his lower legs, with a high-stepping gait and foot drop on examination. His parents report he has been hoarse and occasionally chokes while swallowing since early childhood. Neurological assessment reveals diminished deep tendon reflexes and reduced pinprick and vibration sensation in the distal limbs. Electromyography demonstrates predominantly axonal neuropathy. Family history is negative for neuropathy, and genetic testing confirms autosomal recessive mutations associated with Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, axonal type, with vocal cord paresis. Laryngoscopy shows bilateral vocal cord paresis contributing to dysphonia. Supportive care with physical therapy and speech therapy is initiated to address functional impairments.Have you noticed whether your weakness tends to get worse after certain activities, like talking for a long time or climbing stairs, or at specific times of day, such as in the evenings or mornings?
output: Umm, I guess I feel kind of more tired or weak sometimes after talking a lot or when I try to do stairs, but I’m not really sure if it’s worse at certain times of day. It just feels kind of the same most of the time.
